translated: Essential Methods of the Sutra on Five Gates of Meditation
Composed by the Great Meditation Master Buddhamitra
Translated by the Song Dynasty Kashmiri Tripiá¹­aka Master *Dharmamitra
There are five gates in the essential methods of sitting meditation:
First, counting the breath;
Second, contemplation of impurity;
Third, cultivation of loving-kindness;
Fourth, contemplation of conditions;
Fifth, mindfulness of the Buddha.
The two gates of counting the breath and contemplation of impurity, and the contemplation of conditions, these three gates have internal and external objects;
Mindfulness of the Buddha and cultivation of loving-kindness take external objects as their objects.
The reason for the five gates is according to the illnesses of the multitude:
If one has much distracted thought, one is taught counting the breath;ğŸ”½If one has much greed and attachment, one is taught contemplation of impurity;
If one has much anger and hatred, one is taught cultivation of loving-kindness;
If one has much attachment to self, one is taught contemplation of conditions;ğŸ”½If the mind is sunken, one is taught mindfulness of the Buddha.
If the practitioner has already had a wholesome mind but has not yet contemplated the samÄdhi of mindfulness of the Buddha, one is taught to single-mindedly contemplate the Buddha.

When contemplating the Buddha, one should contemplate the Buddha's excellent characteristics with utmost sincerity, clearly and distinctly. After clearly understanding, then close the eyes and keep it in mind;
If it is not clear, open the eyes again to observe, and be extremely clear in the mind before sitting again.
Correct the body and mind, focus the thoughts in front, just like facing the true Buddha, clearly without difference.
Then get up from the seat, kneel and say to the teacher:
In my room, I focused my thoughts and saw the Buddha without difference.
The teacher says:
You return to your original seat and focus your thoughts on the forehead, single-mindedly contemplating the Buddha.
At that time, there will be a Buddha image appearing on the forehead, from one to ten, up to countless.
If the practitioner sees many Buddhas emerging from the forehead, or if they go not far from the body and return, the teacher should know that this is a person seeking to become a Å›rÄvaka.
If they go a little further and return, it is a person seeking to become a pratyekabuddha.
If they go far and return, it is a person of the Great Vehicle.

The three kinds of Buddhas that emerge return to the body, and the ground becomes golden in color. All these Buddhas enter the ground, and the ground becomes flat like the palm of a hand, bright and clear like a mirror.
Observe one's own body, bright and clear like the ground. This is called attaining the realm of the samadhi of mindfulness of the Buddha.
Having attained this realm, inform the teacher.
The teacher says:
This is a good realm.
This is called the initial stage of contemplation.
The teacher further instructs to focus the mind on the heart, and then contemplate the Buddha.
One will see the Buddhas emerge from the heart, holding a crystal staff, with the three vehicles emerging from both ends of the staff, with the light flames being large or small.
After emerging in this way, the last Buddha holds the staff in the heart and stands still. The last Buddha turns around and enters back, and the Buddhas who left earlier all come and enter together.
If the followers of the Lesser Vehicle enter and disappear, it ends there;

If a person of the Mahayana enters and exhausts, all emerge from the pores of the body, filling the four seas, reaching the peak of existence above and the wind-limit below. After illuminating in this way, they return and enter the body like pure lapis lazuli.
The reason the light returns and enters the body is to demonstrate the appearance of a courageous and swift realm.
Having done so, they immediately go and inform the teacher.
The teacher says:
This is called the foundation of mindfulness of all things, because it can give rise to various concentrations, it is called the foundation of mindfulness.
Also, initially attaining this Dharma,
it is all obtained by the disciples of the Buddhas, not seen by the sages of the wrong paths.
The upper staff is the appearance of concentration.
The appearance of light is the appearance of wisdom.
This is the appearance of the realm of the inner ordinary beings.
The teacher further teaches, saying:
From now on, you should abandon the previous two contemplations and focus your mind on the navel.
He immediately accepts the teacher's instruction and single-mindedly contemplates the navel.
Observing for a while, he realized that the Buddha's body had a moving appearance, but he looked at it intently without distraction.
He saw that the Buddha's body had a substance, like a goose egg, its color fresh and white.
He immediately went to report to his teacher.
The teacher said:
You should observe again where it is.
As instructed by the teacher, he saw that there was a lotus flower, with a stem of lapis lazuli and a golden pedestal, on which there was a Buddha sitting in full lotus position.
In the middle of the first Buddha's body, there was another lotus flower emerging, on which there was another Buddha sitting in full lotus position.

In this way, they emerged one after another until they reached the great ocean, with the first Buddha at the edge of the ocean entering the body of the second Buddha, the second Buddha entering the body of the third Buddha, and so on, returning to the Buddha in the practitioner's body.
After each Buddha had entered the practitioner's body, lotus flowers emerged from all the pores of the practitioner's body, filling the sky like hanging jeweled necklaces.
In this way, they will see all the lotus flowers enter the navel.
At that time, the practitioner's body will become soft and light, and they will see their own body clear and pure, with the colors of various jewels. They should report what they see to the teacher.
The teacher will say:
Very good.
You should focus your mind and observe the signs of attaining concentration in this body.
The teacher will instruct:
Observe further in the navel.
As instructed, they will see a five-colored light flame at the crown of the head.
Having seen it, they will report to the teacher.
The teacher will say:
Observe further in the five lights for the five auspicious signs.
As instructed, they will see a Buddha sitting in full lotus posture in the light. They will further observe what auspicious signs there are in the five lights.
They will then see various lotus flowers emerging from the Buddha's mouth, filling the entire earth upon emerging.

Further, have them observe that among the five lights, one Buddha appears. When the Buddha appears, five lions emerge from the Buddha's navel. After the lions emerge and devour the flowers that were emitted, they return and enter into the Buddha's navel among the five lights.
After the lions enter, the five lights and the Buddha then enter from the crown of the head.
This is called the characteristic of the lion's exertion samÄdhi.
The practitioner further observes that the lights enter the Buddha's body, and the practitioner's body becomes golden in color.
Having seen the golden color, they see an object in the Buddha's navel, round like the sun and moon, white and bright.
Having seen it, they inform the teacher.
The teacher says:
Observe further.ğŸ”½They then see a Buddha emerge and fill the armpits, and a Buddha emerges from the waist, with a total of four Buddhas emerging.
After the four Buddhas emerge, they see the bodies of the four Buddhas, and each Buddha emits immeasurable round sun-like lights, the lights are extremely bright and pure.
Due to the sunlight, one sees the colors of the four continents, up to the peak of existence and down to the wind-wheel, all clearly, as if seeing the palm of one's hand, unobstructed.
This is called the realm of the white-pure liberation.
Having seen this, one sees the four Buddhas return to where they came from.

After the four Buddhas have entered, one sees white flames and lights, entering from the front and exiting from the back, entering from the back and exiting from the front, entering from the left and exiting from the right, entering from the right and exiting from the left.
After these four kinds of entering and exiting are done, one sees one's own body bright and pure, and the pure light completely filling the four sides of the water.
This is called the realm of bright purity.
Having seen this light, it is called accomplishing the samÄdhi of mindfulness of the Buddha, which is in the fourth dhyÄna.

For one practicing the method of impurity, when the wholesome mind comes to the teacher's place and has not yet received the teaching, the teacher first instructs them to sit upright in the room for seven days.
If there are conditions, one will be aware of trembling in the body and its surroundings, and will see one's own body clearly, with a white dew like a pearl on the toenail of the left big toe.
The practitioner should rise from their seat and report what they have realized to the teacher.
The teacher instructs the practitioner in the postures of walking, standing, sitting, and lying down.
If the practitioner's inner realm is abundant, they will look far and high, knowing that external conditions are abundant.
If they walk slowly with single-minded attention and look carefully, they will know that the conditions are internal.
If the conditions are external, they should be taught to observe a corpse between burial mounds.
Having seen it, they return to their room and sit, observing their own body.

If they do not lose the contemplation of bones for three days, they should next observe the people in the room, gradually causing them to see white bones, continuing in sequence up to the great ocean.
By what sign does one reach the great ocean?
By seeing the source of the water waves.

All the skeletons and one's own body are adorned with necklaces, and one sees great water coming to drench one's head and fill one's body. After filling one's body, it causes it to flow out from the feet and form a river of blood.
This is called the samÄdhi of disgust.
Again, focus the mind on the front, and see everything lying down, with only one's own body remaining.
Report this to the teacher.
The teacher says:
You should observe your own body and divide it into five parts.
The reason for dividing it into five parts is to know the inner and outer perceptions as a test.
If the body can be destroyed and divided into five parts, then one knows that now there is no self, and each part also has no self. The mind then abides in the gate of samÄdhi on no-self.
When abiding in samÄdhi, one sees knives coming out from all the limbs and joints, and the edges of the knives all emit bright flames. This is called the realm of the wisdom of no-self.
Again, focus the mind on the white bones, and one sees a bright star coming out on the bones, with golden spheres on the four sides.
The star represents the realm of bright purity.
The golden ball refers to the realm of wisdom and the twenty-five.
This is called the completion of the realm of white bones.
Among the ten contemplations, the appearance of white bones is briefly extracted.
Although the practitioner sees white bones, he still gives rise to a lustful mind due to the colors of men and women. In order to eliminate lust, he should contemplate the thirty-six substances.

When contemplating, he should focus his mind on the forehead. If he focuses his mind for not too long, he will see a bright pearl appearing in front of his forehead, preventing it from falling, in order for his mind to firmly abide.
The reason there is this appearance is because the Dharma stream appears.
In this way, before long, he is instructed to let go and enter the ground. After entering the ground, he follows and observes it, bright and pure, passing through the earth element.
The reason this is known is because he himself sees his body and everywhere sees frost and ice passing through the wind element.
The reason this is known is because the body is soft and supple, passing through the water element.
The reason we know this is because we see our own bodies and there is water everywhere, with bubbles on top that reach the wind realm.
The reason we know this is because we see our own bodies like a space pearl.
If we follow the emptiness and return, the bright and pure light follows the pearl.
If the pearl comes out and enters the practitioner's navel, after entering we see the thirty-six substances clearly without obstruction.
At that time, the practitioner attains the definite completion of the male and female characteristics.
The method of contemplating white bones.
As for contemplating white bones, remove the flesh, blood, sinews, and veins of the body, and the bones support each other, white like conch shells, and the light is also like this.
If one does not see it, it is like a leper. The doctor tells the patient's family:
If you make them drink blood that turns the same color as milk, then they can be cured.
All the things in the house are made white, and a silver vessel is used to hold the blood, and it is said:
Drink the milk, and this illness will surely be cured.
The patient says:
It is blood.
The master replied:
Use a white object to treat it.
Have you not seen that all the objects in the household are white? It is because of your sin that you see blood.
You should focus your mind on the milk and not think of it as blood.
In this way, after seven days, it turned into milk. How much more so for something that is truly white, which you will be able to see.
You will then see a skeleton person, and the arising and ceasing of the mind within the skeleton person will be like a string of beads.
What you see in this way, as well as observing the external body, is also like this.
If the mind abides and diligence is not neglected, like drilling for fire and seeing smoke, or digging a well and seeing mud, obtaining water is not far off.
If the mind abides in stillness, opening the eyes and seeing the skeleton is clear, like still water reflecting the face;
turbid water does not reflect.

The SamÄdhi of Contemplating the Buddha, the Buddha is the Dharma King, able to cause people to attain various wholesome dharmas. Therefore, those who sit in meditation should first contemplate the Buddha.
The Buddha can make people's immeasurable offenses become light and attain various meditative absorptions. If one thinks of the Buddha with a sincere mind, the Buddha also thinks of that person.
If one is thought of by the king, enemies and creditors cannot encroach upon them.
It is the same with thinking of the Buddha; other evil dharmas cannot disturb them.
If one thinks of the Buddha, but the Buddha is not in the world, how can one recollect him?
People's self-confidence is no greater than their eyes. One should contemplate the image as if seeing the true Buddha, without any difference.
First, from the flesh-colored topknot and the white tuft between the eyebrows, down to the feet, and then back to the flesh-colored topknot, carefully contemplate each mark.
Again, in a quiet place, close the eyes and contemplate, focusing the mind on the image, preventing other thoughts. If there are other conditions, restrain them and bring them back.
The mind itself observes and can see as one wishes. This is attaining the contemplation of the meditative absorption of conditions.
One should think like this:
I also do not go, and the image also does not come. The reason I can see it is because the mind is in meditative absorption and the thoughts abide.
After attaining the samÄdhi of contemplating the Buddha, one can then progress to contemplate the physical body and immediately see it as if facing it in person.
The human mind is scattered and often involves evil dharmas. One should be like a wet-nurse watching over a child and not allow them to do evil.
If the mind does not abide, one should reproach oneself:
The suffering of old age, sickness, and death always comes to oppress.
If born in the heavens, attached to wonderful desires, there are no wholesome dharmas to treat the mind.
If falling into the three evil destinies, suffering and fear cause the wholesome mind not to arise.
Now, in this body, one should single-mindedly contemplate the Buddha.
One should further contemplate and say:

Born in the latter age when the Dharma is about to perish, it is like beating a drum, opening the gate, and releasing prisoners. As the drum sound gradually ceases and the gate closes, how can one not know and not seek to leave the prison?
From the beginningless world in the past, through birth and death, the suffering and distress experienced are myriad.
Now, having just received the Dharma, I have not yet attained accomplishment. The thief of impermanence always comes to harm me, and I experience the suffering of birth and death for countless eons.

In this way, various admonitions are used to make the mind dwell on the characteristics. Whether sitting, lying down, walking, or standing, one always sees the Buddha. Then, one further advances to contemplate the physical body.
After attaining meditative concentration, it becomes easier to contemplate the physical body.

As for the contemplation of the Dharma body, since one has already contemplated the image and the mind follows the thought to accomplishment, one gathers the mind and enters concentration, and then one immediately sees it.
One should use the image to give rise to thoughts of the physical body.
Contemplate it as if it were sitting under the Bodhi tree, with radiant and illuminating characteristics that are extraordinary.
Also, as if it were in the Deer Park, expounding the Dharma of the Four Noble Truths to the five bhikshus.
Also, as if it were on Mount Gridhrakuta, emitting great light and expounding the Prajnaparamita to the great assembly.

Use any one place, focus the mind in front, and do not allow it to scatter externally. When the thought in the mind can dwell, one immediately sees the Buddha, and the entire body is blissful, penetrating to the bones and marrow.
It is like obtaining a cool pond in hot weather or a warm room in cold weather. No worldly pleasure can compare with it.

As for contemplating the Dharma body, having already seen the Buddha's physical body in emptiness, one should use the physical body to contemplate the inner Dharma body, the ten powers, the four fearlessnesses, the eighteen distinctive abilities, great compassion, and immeasurable wholesome karma.
It is like a person who first sees a golden vase and later contemplates the maá¹‡i jewel inside the vase.

The reason the Dharma body is truly wondrous, spiritual, and incomparable is that it has no near or far, no difficulty or ease. Immeasurable worlds are all like before one's eyes, and there is not a single dharma that is not known. All dharmas are completely understood.
Therefore, practitioners should always be mindful and not let their minds be scattered. If they think of other conditions, they should be restrained and brought back.
Furthermore, all those who have passed away know that when they are about to die, they first lose their faculties.
Like throwing oneself into a fire pit, the sound reaches the Brahma Heaven.
There is nothing more terrifying than the thief of death, only the Buddha alone has the power to save and deliver, bestowing various human, heavenly, and nirvÄá¹‡a-like happiness.
Furthermore, all Buddhas, lifetime after lifetime, always do not spare their lives for the sake of all sentient beings.
Like ÅšÄkyamuni Buddha, when he was a prince, he went out on an excursion and saw a leper. He ordered a doctor, saying:
You must drink the blood of a living person and apply the marrow to him in order to cure him.
The prince thought:
This person is difficult to find.
Even if there is one, it is not permissible to harm him, as one would be cured and the other would die.
He then gave his own body to the leper to be cured.

The Buddha is like this for all sentient beings. The Buddha's kindness is profound and heavy, surpassing that of parents. Suppose all sentient beings were divided into two groups, one should think of the Buddha in one group, and should not think of anything else in the other group.
Such various merits should be practiced according to one's thoughts.
If this thought is accomplished, one can sever the bonds and fetters, and even attain the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas.
If various illnesses arise in the meantime, one should take medicine according to the illness.

If one does not attain concentration, one will be the most honored among the six desire heavens, with palaces following one's actions and deeds, or be born in front of the buddhas without any lack of concentration.
It is like mixing medicine with red copper. If it does not become gold, one does not lose the silver.

Contemplating the buddhas of the ten directions and thinking of the buddhas of the ten directions means sitting and contemplating the east, with a vast and bright light, no mountains, rivers, or stone walls, and only seeing one buddha sitting in full lotus position with his hand raised, expounding the Dharma.

Clearly observe the characteristics of the light and excellent features, vividly and clearly, and focus the mind on the buddha, not allowing other thoughts. If the mind thinks of other things, restrain it and bring it back.
Seeing in this way, one then increases to ten buddhas.
After seeing, one further increases to a hundred buddhas, a thousand buddhas, and even to boundless bodies.
Those nearby will become more distant and more extensive, only seeing the light of the buddhas connecting with each other.
If the mind clearly contemplates and attains this, turn the thoughts to the southeast and contemplate as above.
Once accomplished, do the same in the west, north, four directions, above and below.
Having seen the buddhas in each direction, further simultaneously contemplate the buddhas in the ten directions, and in a single thought, the range will be complete and you will see them all.

Those who have accomplished the concentrated mind will see the buddhas in the ten directions expounding the Dharma within concentration, and all doubts will be eliminated, attaining the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas.

If there are past offenses and causes and conditions, and one does not see the buddhas, one should repent, make requests, and rejoice in the six periods of the day and night, and gradually one will see them.
Even if one makes requests and they do not expound the Dharma, this person's mind will be joyful and the body will be at ease without illness.

When first practicing sitting meditation, first teach them to focus their attention on the big toe of the right foot, seeing it swell up, and with their mind, scratch it, causing yellow liquid to flow out like pus and blood, and the flesh to rot away, leaving only white bones.
When they see this completely, they should be taught the bone contemplation extensively.
If they see it filling the entire world, they should be taught the Mahayana.
If they see it nearby, they should be taught the Hinayana.

Teach them to focus their attention on the tip of the nose and imagine that the human body's flesh and muscles are all formed from the impure essence of the parents, and next contemplate the white teeth, that in the human body there are only these white bones.
If they see the teeth long or the forehead white, then contemplate the bones, causing the whole body to become white, far and near as above.

This person, according to the depth of their faculties, if when taught they cannot suddenly see the white bones, teach them the usual nine contemplations, to cultivate for one month or one autumn, only proceeding when they see the white bones.
If one sees sentient beings teaching the contemplation of loving-kindness, teaching the mature contemplation of white bones, or seeing other objects, one should tell the practitioner:
This is also good, but let us put it aside for now and only contemplate the white bones.
The practitioner should then contemplate the white bones for a long time and say:
I feel warmth in my body.
The teacher should instruct them to continue contemplating.
If they see warmth and feel peaceful and joyful, this is the warmth stage.
Next, the teacher should instruct them to mentally dissolve the white bones, causing them to disintegrate joint by joint.
If they see other objects, they should be told to put them aside for now and only contemplate the white bones disintegrating.
After contemplating for a long time, if they say:
Fire emerges from the top of my head,
the teacher should instruct them to contemplate further.
They say:
I always see fire emerging from the top of my head.
The body feels blissful and free from chaotic thoughts, this is the peak stage.

Next, instruct them to focus their attention, causing the bones to become pure white, then scattered and blown away, falling to the ground like snow on the ground, or like rotten soil with white light and various other things on top.
Instruct them to observe further.
If they say:
I continue to see this, and my body feels blissful.
You should tell them:
Recall the person you loved in the past and think about the worldly affairs you did with them.
After observing, they say:
I recall that person, but I only see them transform into pus, blood, and impurities, which is extremely disgusting to behold.
Next, instruct them to observe the body as if it were a bundle of grass or an empty leather bag.
If they say:
I see my own body as a bundle of dry grass or an empty leather bag, and when the fire burns it all away, there is no longer any 'I'.
Instruct them to observe further:
When your mind arises, from where does it arise?
When it ceases, from where does it cease? Observe this.
The observer should say in conclusion:
I see that when the corpse suddenly awakens, it arises from the mind. When it perishes, it perishes at the top of the nose.
When the top of the nose perishes, the body is harmoniously still, and I am unaware of myself, clearly and distinctly.
He taught her to observe the top of her head, saying:
I see the body growing tall, with water emerging from the top of the head and filling the body, causing it to be completely full, flowing out from the middle onto the ground in front.
When the water emerging is exhausted, he taught her to lower the water again, causing the body to be coarse and large.
If she says:
I see the body large, with water filling it, flowing out to form a large pool of water,
he taught her to pour ghee on the top of her head, causing it to enter her body.
If she says:
I pour ghee on the top of my head, and my body becomes vast,
he taught her to observe it carefully.
If she says:

Observing for a moment, I see the skin giving rise to fire, the fire then blazing and filling the body, extinguishing it with water, causing the fire to be completely extinguished and feeling greatly relieved.
The teacher should instruct the practitioner to contemplate the pond.
The practitioner replies:
I see that in the pond there are trees growing naturally, and the trees bear sweet fruits.
Having seen these fruits, if there are sentient beings who come hungry and seek them, the observer sees this and teaches compassion, then contemplating one's own body.
If one says:
I contemplate my own body, and pus and blood flow out onto the ground. Sentient beings see it and take it to eat. Having eaten their fill, they each go in the four directions.
The teacher should instruct the practitioner to contemplate their own body and the bodies of others.
If one says:
One then sees many hungry ghosts come and surround one's body, their lives as fragile as a hair, tormented by hunger and starvation.
One should then teach with a compassionate mind to give one's body to them.
If one says:
I give my body to them, and they are satisfied.
The teacher should instruct the practitioner to contemplate further.
If one says:
I see countless sentient beings surrounding my body on all four sides.
If one sees this, one should be taught to contemplate one's own body.
If they say:
I see my own body's impure pus and blood on the ground, and beings see it and take it to eat.
After they are satisfied, instruct them to observe carefully:
I see a fire suddenly arise, burning the sinful people and my own body, and everything in the pond is already completely gone.
Again, instruct them to observe carefully where they see it.
If they say:
I see beings and the water in the pond and my own body all restored as before.
Observe beings and their own bodies.
If they say:
I see milk flowing out from my own body and onto the ground, and beings see it but cannot eat it, because of the heaviness of their sins.
Teach them to contemplate with a compassionate mind.
If they say:

In an instant, the milk turns into pus, and the beings, starving, eat it. After they are satisfied, they see fire burning at the soles of their feet, burning the beings and suddenly extinguishing them.
When the practitioner sees this, they should be taught to make a vow themselves not to accept rebirth.
They are taught to continue contemplating the pond in front.
If they say:
I see a water pond, with lotus flowers and lush tree branches and leaves.

Having seen this, my body enters the water and sits by the edge of the grove. I see fire coming out from within my body, filling the pond. In an instant, the fire suddenly arises, burning my own body and all beings, and the pond water completely dries up.
They are taught to continue contemplating.
If they say:
I see a tree suddenly growing in the pond, with lush branches and leaves, producing sweet fruits.
The practitioner sees it and goes to the tree to eat the fruits.
Having eaten to their fill, their body and mind become clear, pure, peaceful, and blissful.
They are taught to purify their contemplation of this pond and their own body.
If they say:
In an instant, it all withers and dries up.
The practitioner, seeing this destructive appearance, becomes frightened and comes to inform the teacher.
The teacher should teach them to contemplate the body as the root of suffering, causing them to view the body as like a bubble.
If they say:
I see my own body as like a bubble, and the body emits bones, which I then use my hands to rub like flour and make into the ground.
Then continue to teach them to contemplate the body as like a bellows.
If they say:
I contemplate myself as like a bellows, and the bones transform and emerge. The bones are fine and smooth, and I rub them to smear on the ground, and the ground becomes green.
Again teach them to contemplate the body.
If they say:
I contemplate the fine dust of my own body and the bones that emerge from the body. The bones are extremely black, and I rub them to make into the ground.
Teach them to contemplate their own body and the ground.
They reply:
I contemplate the pond, and a snake emerges. The body is red like fire. The snake comes to pester the body, and it transforms into fire and burns the body itself.
In this way, it happens seven times.
Water will naturally appear in the seat and sprinkle it, and the snake's body will then disappear.
The teacher should then instruct them to observe their body and the ground again.
If they say:
I observe that in an instant, a natural light appears, lofty and bright.
Then continue to observe the body.
If they say:
I feel harmonious and comfortable, with a joyful mind and body, without any slackening, and a natural light comes and fills the entire body.
Instruct them to observe their body seven times.
If they say:
I then see a light on the top of my head, like a cloud canopy, its color like silver.
If these things are complete, they should be at the beginning of the path, and it is also called the completion of observing fire.
Next, observe the water element, and instruct them to observe where there is water in the body.
If they say:
The entire body is water.
Instruct them to observe further.
If they say:
I see water appearing in the eyes. This is good.
If not attached:
You observe where the water above the head comes from.
If he says:
I see the water coming from the eyes, and it does not fall to the ground.
The eyes are like water bubbles, and the head is also full.
The master should ask:
What does the water you see look like?
What are the characteristics when it comes out?
He replies:
I see that the water in the head is neither warm nor cold.
Very good.
If he says the water is warm, know it is not true, and teach him to observe again, making sure the water is neither warm nor cold, which is the true appearance.
Teach him to observe from the throat to the abdomen, making him see the water filling up, but not letting it enter his arms and legs.
The water must be the color of crystal.
If he feels the water is warm, then it is true, the rest is not true.
Next, observe throughout the body, including the arms and legs.
If he says:ğŸ”½I see the characteristics of a skin bag.
And I see the water filling the house and the place of the bed and seat.
If the water is cold, it is true, the rest is not true.
If you see water extensively, it is very good.
Next, contemplate where the water element ends.
If you say:
I see the water in my body dissipating, leaving only an empty skin or like a bundle of grass, fire arises and burns it all up, and I am gone.
Contemplation of the water element is finished.
Next, contemplate the fire element, and teach them to observe where there is fire on the four sides.
If you say:
I see fire arising above me.
Or if you say it comes out of the nose, mouth, eyes, or ears, teach them to contemplate further.
They reply:
I see five-colored light coming out of the nose, its shape like silk, and the body is neither warm nor cold.
This is one method, teach them to contemplate further.
If you say:
I see fire coming out from the top of the head, or from the lower path.
Instruct them to observe again.
They say:
I see fire above my head like a cloud-shaped canopy, or it is below like a cloud-shaped, my body is serene and at ease.
This is one method, instruct them to observe the body again.
They say:
I see fire emerging from the waist, like a lotus flower, its color like gold.
Very good, instruct them to observe the fire in the body.
If they say:
I see fire whether walking or sitting, not only when sitting.
When walking, I see fire, like a person holding fire, always in front of me, very bright.
I wonder if others notice it, but others actually do not see it, yet my body is always warm.
This is one method, instruct them to observe for a longer time.
They say:
I see the great ocean water, within it there is a maá¹‡i jewel, its light emits like fire.
This jewel is one method.
The method of observing the fire element is completed.
Next, contemplate the wind element. This wind element is subtle by nature and is not understood by those who are not well-versed, so it is not mentioned.
These four elements are the basis for the practice of meditation. Although one may see many other phenomena, one should focus on observing these four.
First, when teaching the contemplation of the Buddha, one should first teach the practitioner to sit in concentration, not allowing external thoughts and distractions.
Then, bring them to a statue in front and have them carefully observe the excellent characteristics of the statue.
Then, sit in meditation and teach them to observe the excellent characteristics of the Buddha with their mind's eye.
If they say:
I clearly see the statue.
This is the first step.
Teach them to observe their own body, to sit in meditation, and to observe the Buddha again.
If they say:
I see one to ten Buddhas, all clearly.
This is the second step.
Teach them to observe their own body in detail and to sit in meditation, and to observe the Buddha again.
If they say:
I see ten to twenty Buddhas clearly.
These are the three things.
Instruct them to observe their own bodies, causing their bodies to become more peaceful and pure, and to observe the Buddha again.
If they say:
I see twenty Buddhas up to fifty Buddhas, as clear as before.
These are the four things.
Instruct them to observe their own bodies, causing their minds to become more subtle, and to observe the Buddha again.
If they say:
I see fifty Buddhas up to a hundred Buddhas, with the same excellent characteristics as before.
These are the five things.
Instruct them to observe their own bodies, causing their minds to become more subtle, and to observe the Buddha again.
If they say:
I see a hundred Buddhas up to a thousand Buddhas, as clear as before.
These are the six things.
Instruct them to observe their own bodies, causing their minds to become more subtle, and to observe the Buddha again.
If they say:
I see two hundred Buddhas up to four hundred Buddhas, clearer than before.
These are the seven things.
Instruct them to observe their own bodies, causing their minds to become more subtle, and to observe the Buddha again.
If they say:
I see four hundred Buddhas up to eight hundred Buddhas, their marks becoming brighter.
This is the eighth matter.
Teach yourself to contemplate the body to make the mind more subtle, and then teach yourself to contemplate the Buddha.
If you say:
I see eight hundred Buddhas up to a thousand Buddhas.
This is the ninth matter.

From one Buddha to a thousand Buddhas, contemplate the marks carefully to make them extremely clear, and then contemplate your own body as impure and bloody, and then teach yourself to contemplate impurity.
If you see white bones, then contemplate white bones.
If you see suffering sentient beings, then contemplate kindness.
If you do not see these things, then contemplate one Buddha, with utmost sincerity, seeking pity and repenting.
This is the contemplation of the Buddha method for beginners.
If you wish to enter the stage of abiding, you should extensively contemplate the Buddha.
If you say:
I see one Buddha up to a hundred thousand myriads of Buddhas, and the marks are clear.
This is the tenth matter.
Instruct them to observe their own bodies, making their bodies bright and pure, and then instruct them to observe the Buddha again, give rise to great vows, and generate offerings.
Say:
I see immeasurable Buddhas, and flowers naturally appear in front of the Buddhas. I then take them to make offerings, covering everywhere.
These are the eleven matters.
Instruct them to observe their own bodies, making their bodies bright and pure, and then instruct them to observe the Buddha again.
If they say:
I see as before, and my mind gives rise to joy.
Instruct them to observe the Buddha with utmost sincerity, thinking of making offerings.
If they say:

I see flower trees spontaneously emerging, producing various colored flowers, and people naturally take these beautiful flowers to offer to the Buddhas, covering everywhere without the flowers being exhausted.
These are the twelve matters.

Next, instruct them to sit by the Buddha, observe their own bodies, making them extremely bright and pure, and then instruct them to start from the east, letting their minds travel east to see innumerable Buddhas, and rest when their minds are tired.
These are the thirteen matters.
Teach the previous realm, then proceed east.
If one says:
My intention is to proceed east, seeing countless Buddhas filling the sky with no boundaries, and only stop when my mind is tired.
Again, turn the mind and proceed east, only stopping when there is obstruction, and the same is true for the south, west, and north.
These are the fourteen matters.
Teach to observe the limbs and joints within one's own body, all becoming clear.
If one says:
I see this.
Teach to observe the Buddha's feet again.
If one says:
I see the mixed light under the Buddha's feet, and then return to the four directions, all Buddhas are in the light above the lotus flowers.
These are the fifteen matters.
Teach to give rise to the joyful mind of observing the Buddha, and carefully observe the feet.
If one says:
I see light emitting from under the Buddha's feet, reaching the great earth with no boundaries.
Teach to observe by riding on this light.
If one says:
I see countless suffering beings, all peaceful and happy where the light reaches.
These are the sixteen things.
Instruct them to contemplate their own bodies, making them even brighter and purer, and to contemplate one Buddha at the navel.
If they say:
I see light emerging from the Buddha's navel, reaching to the farthest reaches in the four directions, with all Buddhas standing in the light,
this is the seventeenth thing.
Instruct them to follow the light in contemplation.
If they say:
I see countless people appearing in the light, all experiencing bliss,
this is the eighteenth thing.
Instruct them to contemplate their own bodies, making them extremely bright and pure, and to contemplate one Buddha's two breasts.
If they say:
I see natural light emerging from the Buddha's two breasts, reaching to the four directions, with all Buddhas in the light,
this is the nineteenth thing.
Instruct them to follow the light in contemplation.
If they say:
I see in this light countless people all experiencing happiness.
These are the twenty matters.
Instruct to contemplate one's own body and see the body as extremely bright, and then return to contemplate the white hair between the eyebrows of one Buddha.
If one says:
I see light emanating from between the eyebrows, as large as a dou, gradually becoming larger, then rising up and floating in the air.
Instruct to follow the light and contemplate, following which light up?
When the mind is tired, stop, and then continue to follow.
If one says:
I follow it up to the end, reaching where the light ends.
This is the twenty-first matter.
The twenty-second matter is originally missing.
Instruct to follow this flower Buddha, starting from the east.
If one says:
I see the light touching, with countless subtle lights all like what is contemplated.
At the end of this light, there are transformation Buddhas filling the east, the distance between them being five steps.
Instruct to continue going east and contemplate it.
If they say:
I see countless Buddhas.
My mind is tired and I stop.
Instruct them to continue contemplating until they see other appearances in the farthest place, and so on in the south, west, and north.
These are the twenty-three matters.
Instruct them to contemplate their own body.
If they say:
I see my body all bright and pure, like a mass of light.
Instruct them to contemplate the Buddha, make offerings in sequence, and pay homage.
If they say:
I see countless Buddhas in a row. I hold various flowers and scatter them in sequence, making offerings to all the Buddhas everywhere.
These are the twenty-four matters.
Instruct them to contemplate the flowers they have offered.
If they say:
I see the fallen flowers forming a flower canopy beside the Buddha, arranged in rows, majestic and exquisite, all like this.
All the Buddhas are sitting on their seats within the canopy.
These are the twenty-five matters.
Teach them to contemplate the flower canopy.
If they say:
I see the flower canopy gradually rising higher and higher, floating in the air and merging into a single canopy covering all Buddhas,
this is the twenty-sixth matter.
Teach them to contemplate their own bodies.
If they say:
I see my own body huge and great, like a mass of light,
teach them to return to contemplating the Buddha, making offerings in sequence, covering everywhere, and looking up at the canopy.
If they say:
I see below the flowers in the upper canopy, made of the seven treasures, there are flowers, which I take with my hands,
teach them to scatter in all directions, making offerings to all Buddhas, covering everywhere.
This is the twenty-seventh matter.
Teach them to make offerings to the Buddha, seeking their wishes, and then teach them to sit with a focused mind by the side of the Buddha.
If they say:
As soon as I sit, I see a seven-treasure platform spontaneously rising from the ground, with a wonderful color and fragrance. I take it to make offerings to all Buddhas.
These are the twenty-eight matters.
Instruct oneself to contemplate the body, making it extremely clear, and instruct to make it clear.
Instruct to sit by the Buddha and contemplate the offerings of flowers.
If one says:
I see these flowers at the Buddha's feet, forming a lapis lazuli seat.
In sequence, in rows, on the Buddha's seat, the middle path is all made of precious substances, upright and incomparable.
This is the twenty-ninth matter.
Instruct oneself to contemplate the body.
If one says:
I see a smaller body within the body, appearing in two layers, the inside seeing the outside, clear and pure.
Instruct to contemplate the Buddha again.
If one says:
I see all the Buddhas coming and entering the body of one Buddha, without crowding.
This concludes the thirty matters.
Contemplating the Buddha has many matters, so thirty matters are briefly presented to instruct practitioners.

First, the method of compassionate contemplation teaches repentance, purifying body, speech, and mind, making sincere and heartfelt great vows, and then teaching sitting meditation. Then, with mind and eyes, one observes one's own body.
If one says:
I see my own body.
Then observe others' bodies.
If one says:

I see sentient beings suffering in front, with fire burning under their feet, forming a pit of fire burning the sinful people, their bodies rotting with pus and blood flowing into a pool, crying out in high voices with immeasurable pain.
I also see cities surrounding in the four directions.
This is called the first matter.
It teaches giving rise to great vows and a compassionate mind, and contemplating sentient beings carefully.
If one says:

I see sinful people tormented by fire throwing themselves into a pool of pus and blood, and the pus and blood in the pool immediately turn into a pit of fire burning the sinful people, with immeasurable pain, they cry out together with no respite.
This is the second matter.
Instruct them to observe carefully and not to be afraid. Vow to save them and instruct each person to take their place, even if it is many times.
If they say:
I take the place of each person and lead them to the top of the pit to let them recover.
Three things.
Instruct them to observe carefully.
If they say:
I see that in the city gates there are countless people coming to throw themselves into the fire pit and suffer pain again. I take their place and lead them out to a safe place.
Four things.
Instruct them to observe carefully.
If they say:
I see that the people coming through the gates are unceasing and suffering countless hardships.
With the power of my compassionate mind, I touch the gate with my own hands, and the gate is completely destroyed, with the four walls completely shattered.
Five things.
Instruct them to observe with compassion.
If they say:
I see that the people being punished give rise to pity, and tears flow like rain. I catch them with my hands and sprinkle them over the fire pit, and the fire is immediately extinguished.
Six things.
Teach them to contemplate further.
Seeing the fire extinguished, only pus and blood fill the great pit, one's own body emits water and puts it in the pond, the pond's blood is exhausted and its water becomes clear.
Seven things.
Teach them to contemplate carefully.
If they say:
I see a great flower tree growing in the pond, sentient beings seeing this tree come to pick it.
Teach them to drink it and bathe in it to make the body pure.
Eight things.
Teach them to ascend the flower platform themselves.
If they say:
After I ascend the flower platform, I see sentient beings below wanting to ascend as well, so I pull them up and place them among the leaves.
The flower is narrow and small, unable to accommodate them, so I rub the flower with my hands to make it vast and able to accommodate them.
Nine things.
Teach them to contemplate their own body as bright and pure.
If they say:

I also saw the sinful people who were hungry and needed food. With a compassionate mind, food and drink immediately appeared on my body, and I gave it to them, causing them all to be satisfied and to rest. The people all said they had escaped suffering and found happiness.
Ten things.
Teach them to contemplate carefully.

The flower platform grew and appeared in several layers. I then ascended to the second layer and sat peacefully. I called the people below to all come up to the flower platform and they could enjoy peace and stability.
With a compassionate mind, on this flower I provided them with all the necessary things, food and drink to fill them up. With a kind mind, I then spoke the Dharma for them:
'You, due to various evil deeds in your past lives such as creating poisonous fires to burn people's homes, now receive this retribution.
You should repent and eliminate your past sins.'
Eleven things.
Teach them to give rise to a good mind and ascend the flower platform again.
If they say:

I have already brought down the heavy ones and also brought up the light ones. I have given them what they need so that they lack nothing. I have also taught them the Dharma, the retributions in the heavens, human realm, and five paths, causing their minds to open up and understand.
Twelve matters.
Teach to search for flowers above.
If it is said:ğŸ”½I have already brought down the heavy ones among the flowers and also brought up the light ones.
I have given them all.
With a joyful mind, I observe in these flowers, and there are naturally gold, silver, precious treasures, clothing, food and drink, and necessary items, all provided to them.
Heavenly music naturally arrives, and they enjoy happiness according to their wishes. I then teach them the Dharma:
'Your wholesome minds have just arisen, and the fruits of retribution will soon arrive. You will receive these fruits of retribution.'
Thirteen matters.
Teach to increase the joyful mind and ride the flowers upwards.
If it is said:
The flowers above the platform are born in the minds of the people below with joy, and later they ascend to the end of the flowers.
Again, teach to contemplate the flowers.
If it is said:
I see the top of the flower.
I see a large sweet fruit born at the top of the flower, complete with fragrance and flavor.
I tell the people:
'There are fruits on the tree that can be picked and eaten.'
Then, as I say, I eat until I am full, and all say it is delightful.
The fourteenth matter.
Teach to contemplate in the flowers.
If it is said:
I see in the flowers a seven-jeweled platform naturally appearing, and within it is a sutra called Wisdom.
I immediately proclaim to all the people:
'In this sutra, the Dharma of the Three Vehicles is taught. You should pay homage and give rise to a respectful mind, offering flowers and incense.
' Again, wanting to listen to the Dharma, I reply:
'Burn incense and scatter flowers.'
After making offerings, wanting to listen to the Dharma again.
I then replied:
I and the assembly are all impure, how can we hear it?
The Dharma purifies body and mind.
So I accepted the teaching.
I told the people:
All of you sit upright, close your eyes, focus your minds, and eliminate all chaotic thoughts.
I did the same, and in an instant, my body became completely bright and my mind and thoughts were at ease.
I then said to them:
Now I will explain this wonderful Dharma for you, listen with utmost sincerity.
So they accepted the teaching.
I explained the Dharma for them, enabling them to hear the Dharma.
After hearing the Dharma, there was a natural light in the sky that illuminated this flower platform, making everything in the four directions completely bright.
These people, seeing the light and rejoicing, their bodies light and elated, followed the light and left.
fifteen matters.
Teach to contemplate the body.
If it is said:
I myself see my body emitting light, circling around my body on all four sides, its radiance becoming increasingly intense, and I then use my hand to push this light far to the four directions.
There are countless people who follow the light and come to me. With a compassionate mind, I provide them with their needs, allowing them to attain fullness and be without any lack.
I then expound the Dharma for them, enabling them to attain faith and understanding, joyfully accepting and practicing. In an instant, I then leap into the air and depart, hovering in the sky.
Sixteen matters.
Teach to contemplate the flower platform.
If it is said:
I see that everything on the flower platform has already gone, and I do not see anything at all, in the four directions it is pure.
Within this matter, the realm is also vast, only the existing is briefly brought out.
Continue the teaching to cultivate the meditation on compassion, first teach to contemplate one's own body with a compassionate mind.
Having seen it clearly, then teach to contemplate sentient beings suffering from pain.
If it is said:
I saw in the four mountains a great hell, filled with sinners suffering great pain.
In an instant, there suddenly appeared an iron canopy covering the sinners, making them invisible.
The first matter.
He was taught to have a compassionate mind and make a great vow:
I will save and deliver immeasurable suffering sentient beings, enabling them to attain liberation. Then, with a compassionate mind, sit on the iron canopy and break through this iron canopy.
If he says:
I will use this hand to shatter the iron canopy, gradually causing it to be completely destroyed, and then look down to see the sinners suffering great pain.

There is a heavy iron wheel above the head of the person, sometimes in the body, sometimes under the feet, sometimes large and sometimes small, with pus and blood flowing out, the pain immeasurable, with loud cries unbearable.
I also saw immeasurable instruments of punishment punishing the sinners, with immeasurable suffering that cannot be fully described.
The second matter.
and further teach them to make vows and increase their compassionate thoughts towards them.
If they say:
I see these sinners, my heart is filled with pity, and tears flow like rain. The people have obtained a little rest.
Three things.
Teach them to cultivate loving-kindness, replace the sinners, and lead them to a high place, and they will then obtain rest.
In an instant, everyone is like this.
Four things.
Teach them to observe further.
If they say:

I see the high mounds rising on the four sides of hell, in the middle there is a pool of pus and blood, and fire suddenly arises in the four places of the pool, burning the sinners, the pain is unbearable, and they wail and cry out in distress.
If they say:
I see this matter and feel pity in my heart. Water flows out from my hands and sprinkles in the four directions, causing the fire to gradually die down, and they obtain a little rest.
Five things.
Teach them to observe further.
If they say:
I see that in the mountains there are countless people entering hell, suffering immeasurable pain.
Seeing this, my heart was filled with pity, so I built a raft in the pond to replace the sinners, taking them onto the raft to give them rest.
Each person is like this.
Six things.
Teach them to contemplate carefully.
If they say:
I see that people coming between the mountains are endless, suffering continuously.
With the power of my compassionate mind, I grind down these mountains to make them into level ground.
Seven things.
Teach them to sit in the sky above this pond with compassion, and let a little water flow out from their bodies into the pond.
If they say:
After I sit in the sky and let the water flow down into the pond, the pus and blood in the pond flow out in all directions, and the pond becomes clear.
In an instant, fire arises on all sides of the pond, burning up all the pus and blood.
Eight things.
Teach them to sit on the pond with a compassionate mind, observing the four directions.
If they say:
I see an iron wheel and poisonous weapons coming to the seat below me, forming a great platform, and the sinful people each go to the peaceful places in the four directions.
I am on the platform, seeing the fire rising below, burning the entire platform, and the fire going in the four directions, burning everything it reaches.
Nine things.
Teach them to observe in the pond.
If they say:
I see the spring water in the pond expanding, reaching the four directions without end, and lotus flowers growing in the middle, gradually expanding to cover the pond.
Teach them to be in the flower, then observe in the four directions, seeing countless people on the four sides of the pond wanting to come to me. I teach them to wash and purify their bodies.
After their bodies are purified, between the flower petals I open a little, staying on the path below the water, and let all the people ascend to the flower platform.
Ten things.
On the four sides of the pond of teaching and contemplation,
If it is said:
I see that on the four sides of the pond, there are naturally appearing towers that connect with the flowers, allowing people to go up to the towers and quickly rest.
Each person says that although they have obtained pleasure,
After resting, they seek food and drink.
There is nothing to give them, so rain pours from their ten fingers, raining flowers as milk, satisfying everyone.
These are the eleven things.
Teach them to contemplate the flower platform.
If it is said:
I see that in the flower platform, there are more platforms appearing, and on the four sides there are more layers, as vast as before.
I immediately went up and opened a small part between the flower petals, setting up ladders for the people to climb up.
Again, on the platform, they went to the towers in the four directions, following the direction they came from, east, and the other three directions are the same.
Furthermore, with a compassionate mind, observe that in this flower there are naturally necessary things, which are given to the people of the four directions to make them fully satisfied.
Then, for them, he preaches the Dharma:
This body is suffering, without any firmness or strength. It is all due to committing the five heinous crimes in past lives and engaging in evil conduct that one receives this suffering.
Now, repent.
Immediately, as he says, he repents.
These are the twelve matters.
Teach to observe the flower platform.
If he says:
In the center of my flower platform, another multi-storied pavilion emerges. I immediately ascend it and make a ladder.

After the people have ascended and rested on the pavilion, I take food, drink, clothing, and necessary things from the flower and give them to the four directions, making sure they have nothing lacking.
Then, I preach the Dharma for them, bringing immeasurable benefits, and they give rise to the mind of faith, uphold the precepts, and completely carry them out.
The thirteenth matter.
Teach to further observe the flower platform pavilion.
If one says:
I see the flower platform and pavilion born as before, more wonderful than before.
I and the people together search for the upper story as before, each of us goes up to the pavilion, and we are all satisfied and have nothing lacking.
I then expound the Dharma for them, and they accept the teaching and all attain benefit.
This is the fourteenth matter.
Instruct to joyfully contemplate the flowers.
If one says:
The flowers and platform in the pavilion are born as before, I and the people all go up together, I sit on the flowers with a joyful mind.

In an instant, I see the flowers and platform all become golden in color, composed of the seven treasures, and on top there is an inexhaustible treasure trove, with clothing, food and drink, fine and soft musical instruments such as the pipa, and whatever is desired is obtained in abundance.
I then expound the Dharma for them, and they all practice it.
This is the fifteenth matter.
Instruct to further contemplate the flowers.
If one says:
I have already seen a tree emerge from the flower platform, ten zhang tall, with luxuriant branches and leaves producing fragrant and delicious medicine.

Ascending to the top of the tree, I looked down and saw the lower pavilion break apart from below to the fifth level. The people were frightened and each cried out in distress, then they followed the flowers and were among the flowers.
Sixteen things.
Teach to give rise to compassion and save the people.
If it is said:
In the flowers and leaves, pull the people up and place them on the flower heads, then give them sweet fruits to provide for them without lack.

Then expound the Dharma for them, teach them to cultivate meditation to extinguish evils, and let their bodies and minds attain purity, with immeasurable joy, flying through the sky and going wherever they wish.
Seventeen things.
Teach to be on the flowers and look far in the four directions.
If it is said:

I see light clouds and canopies coming from the four directions towards my body. At that time, my body emits light and connects with the canopies. I use my hand to touch them, making them vast and large.
Eighteen things.
The teaching immediately follows the light from the east.
If it is said:

I follow the light and go east for a long time. In this light, I see countless people coming towards the flowers in the light. In this way, I follow and go to where the light resides, and then return to the flowers myself.
The teaching arranges them in order, and provides them with clothing, food, and necessary things to make them feel satisfied.

Then, the Dharma is explained to them, and they joyfully accept and practice according to their abilities. Their bodies feel light and buoyant, and they can fly in the air and go wherever they wish. It is the same in the south, west, and north.
Nineteen things.
The teaching observes the body to be vast and expansive, filling the sky and being extremely clear and pure.
Again, clearly seeing countless people coming from the four directions and gathering around, I use loving-kindness to cause them to enter my body. After entering my body, they settle down.
In an instant, there are naturally the necessary things, which I give to the people according to their wishes, causing them to have nothing lacking, each attaining fullness and blissful peace.
Then I expound the Dharma for them, benefiting them immeasurably, causing them to attain understanding and leave as they wish.
Twenty matters.
There are so many such things, but I only explain this matter for those who receive the Dharma in brief.
There are three grades of physical illness, with wind, cold, and heat being minor.

The mind has three illnesses and afflictions, and the body moves with the number of kalpas, experiencing various sufferings. Only the Buddha, the good doctor, bestows the Dharma medicine, and those who are able to receive it eliminate the illness of birth and death.
Causing the mind to be determined and focused without confusion, like a person who sees a thief, settles the mind, and firmly adorns oneself, the thief will naturally retreat and scatter.
The evil thief of a confused mind is also like this.
He said:
Although the blood and flesh are exhausted, only the skin, tendons, and bones remain.

Do not abandon diligence, just as when a person burns their body they only want to save the fire and have no other plans. Emerging from the suffering of afflictions is also like this. One should endure the suffering of five things:
Hunger, thirst, cold, heat, resentment, and so on.
One should avoid busyness and enjoy being in quiet places.
Why is this?
Busyness disturbs concentration, like entering a forest of thorns.
The method of contemplating the four immeasurables.
Those who seek the Buddha way should practice the four immeasurable minds.
Because the mind is immeasurable, the merits are also immeasurable.
Among all sentient beings, there are generally three categories:
First, parents, relatives, and good friends, second, enemies and evil people who always want to harm, and third, neutral people who are neither close nor hostile.

The practitioner should contemplate these three types of people with a compassionate mind, regarding them as relatives. The elderly are like fathers, and the young are like children. One should always cultivate such a compassionate mind.
One becomes an enemy due to having evil causes. When the evil causes are exhausted, one returns to being a relative. There is no fixed distinction between relatives and enemies.
Why is this?
In this world, one is an enemy, but in the next world, one becomes a relative.
The evil of hatred loses great benefits. Those who lose the compassionate mind obstruct the Buddha's path. Therefore, one should regard hateful enemies as one's relatives.
Why is this?
It is because of these enemies that I attain Buddhahood.
If enemies have no evil towards me, from what arises patience?
This is then a good friend for me, enabling me to attain the perfection of patience.

Having attained a compassionate mind towards enemies, one extends loving kindness and affection towards all sentient beings in the ten directions, universally embracing all, and arouses a compassionate mind for those who are not at peace, including insects and worms.
If one sees sentient beings attaining happiness in this world, attaining the happiness of rebirth in the heavens, and attaining the happiness of the noble path, one gives rise to a joyful mind.

If one does not see any suffering or happiness in sentient beings, one neither loves nor delights, but controls oneself with wisdom. Although one gives rise to a mind of equanimity in relation to sentient beings,
this is called the four immeasurables.
Because loving-kindness pervades sentient beings in the ten directions, it is called immeasurable.
The practitioner should cultivate this mind. Sometimes if a mind of anger arises, like a snake or fire on the body, one should immediately get rid of it.
If the mind wanders and enters the five desires, and is covered by the five hindrances, one should use the power of wisdom and diligence to gather it back.

Cultivating a loving mind, always thinking of sentient beings attaining the happiness of the Buddhas, if one cultivates without ceasing, one will attain liberation from the five desires and eliminate the five hindrances.

The characteristics of entering the first dhyÄna are joy and bliss pervading the body. One gives rise to joy and bliss in all wholesome dharmas and sees various subtle forms. This is called the initial gateway to entering the Buddha's path.

Based on the causes and conditions of the merit and virtue of dhyÄna concentration, one attains the four immeasurable minds. Being patient and not angry towards all sentient beings is called patience towards sentient beings.
Having attained patience towards sentient beings, it is easy to attain patience towards the Dharma.
The one who attains patience towards the Dharma is one who believes and accepts the characteristics of the non-arising and non-ceasing of all dharmas, which are ultimately empty.
The one who is able to believe and accept this Dharma patience is called the patience of non-arising and receives the prediction of attaining supreme perfect enlightenment.
Those who wish to attain the Buddha's path should cultivate and practice in this way.

Those who seek the first dhyÄna should first cultivate these contemplations, either contemplating impurity, or contemplating the twelve links of dependent arising, or the samÄdhi of mindfulness of the Buddha, or counting the breath, and then attain entry into various concentrations.

The Buddha was sitting in meditation by the Ganges River, and a monk with little learning asked the Buddha:

The monk with much learning wondered why he had nothing to gain, and asked the Buddha.

The method of contemplation on impurity: Greed, anger, and delusion are the roots of all illnesses. Attachment to the body and desires gives rise to anger, which is then covered by the delusion of inverted thinking.

Deeply attached to the pure thoughts of self-love and attachment to the inner and outer body, it is difficult to eliminate them. In order to detach from sexual desire, one should contemplate impurity.
Anger arises from external causes, but it can still be controlled.
It is like a person breaking bamboo, the first joint is difficult to break.
Once sexual desire is controlled, the other two will naturally subside.

As for the contemplation of impurity, one should contemplate that this body is born in an impure place, in the womb, and comes out from impurity. The thin skin covers it, and inside it is pure impurity. The four elements transform into food and drink to fill the inside.

One should contemplate from the head to the feet, and inside, wrapped in thin skin, there is not a single pure thing. Brain, membranes, mucus, saliva, pus, blood, feces, and urine, briefly there are thirty-six things, and in detail, there are innumerable.
It is like a farmer opening a granary and skillfully distinguishing hemp, wheat, millet, and beans.

The practitioner deeply contemplates seeing this body's granary, with various impurities and thirty-six things, and distinguishes the internal body as it is. One should know that the external body is also no different from this.
